The electrocatalytic conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) into 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) offers a highly effective and eco-friendly pathway for the utilization of biomass resources. For the widely studied Ni-based electrodes, enhancing their catalytic activity remains challenging due to the sluggish phase transition of Ni(OH)₂ to the active NiOOH. Here, we present a model catalyst of Ni nanoparticles encapsulated by a carbon layer (Ni@C), systematically investigate the role of active sites formed by reconstruction and redispersion in enhancing the electrocatalytic activity, and further explore the effect of HMF concentration on Ni@C reconstruction and redispersion. The encapsulated carbon layer contributes to nickel grain reconstruction and redispersion to form Ni3+ sites, thereby increasing the electrochemically active surface area. A combination of in-situ Raman, HRTEM and XPS characterization analyses showed that high concentrations of HMF electrolytes promoted faster reconstruction and redispersion of Ni grains encapsulated within the carbon layers to generate smaller-sized NiOOH grains, thus significantly improving HMF oxidation. This study establishes a novel catalytic pathway for enhancing HMF electrooxidation performance by reaction-induced reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni@C catalyst 5-hydroxymethylfurfural electrooxidation High concentration Reaction-induced Reconstruction and redispersion 1 Introduction The swiftness of natural fossil fuels has catalyzed a worldwide transition to sustainable and eco-friendly energy development, and biomass is emerging as a widely recognized renewable resource [1–5]. In particular, HMF derived from lignocellulosic biomass is considered a crucial precursor for the production of liquid fuels, pharmaceuticals and plastics due to its versatile chemical structure [6–8]. HMF can be transformed through various pathways, in which the electrocatalytic 5-hydroxymethylfurfural oxidation reaction (HMFOR) stands out for enabling efficient conversion under ambient temperature and pressure, surpassing conventional multiphase catalytic methods [9,10]. Notably, one of the important products obtained from HMF by anodic oxidation reaction is the high value-added FDCA [11,12]. FDCA serves as a critical precursor for synthesizing polyethylene 2,5-furandicarboxylate (PEF), a promising alternative to petroleum-based polyethylene terephthalate (PET). Moreover, FDCA exhibits exceptional mechanical and thermal properties, making it a strong candidate for advancing sustainable and eco-friendly materials [13,14]. Importantly, HMFOR operates at a lower potential than the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which not only produces high-value oxidized products at the anode, but also replaces the OER in coupling with the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2 RR) or hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) to realize the efficient conversion of energy [15–17]. Consequently, in-depth research on HMFOR is of great significance for developing more environmentally benign and economically viable electrocatalytic technologies [18,19]. In the field of electrocatalytic HMF conversion, the choice of electrode materials is crucial to improve the efficiency of HMFOR [20–22]. Extensive research has been conducted on advanced electrocatalysts based on precious metals, including Au [23], Ru [24], Pd [9,25] and Pt [26,27] for HMFOR. However, the high cost limits the further commercial application of the materials, leading to a greater focus on non-precious metal electrocatalysts, particularly those based on Ni, Fe, and Co [28–32]. Among these, low-cost and highly active Ni-based catalysts have proven to be the “star” catalysts for HMFOR [33,34]. Studies have consistently demonstrated that high-valent Ni species (Ni³⁺) and their derived compound NiOOH, serve as the active species in HMFOR [35–37]. Nevertheless, single Ni-based catalysts still face the challenges of lack of active sites and insufficient adsorption capacity for HMF, which limit their catalytic effect in HMFOR [38]. To address these challenges, researchers have explored various strategies, such as incorporating additives and constructing heterojunctions, aimed at increasing the number of active sites and modulating the surface electronic structure of Ni-based catalysts. These modifications promote the oxidation of Ni²⁺ to Ni³⁺ and facilitate the formation of NiOOH, thereby enhancing catalytic performance [39,40]. Recent studies have also highlighted that wrapped non-precious metal catalysts exhibit remarkable electrocatalytic activity, primarily due to in situ redispersion during HMFOR, which generates additional active sites. Nevertheless, these findings are primarily based on low HMF concentrations (10 mM) [41]. The vast majority of the reported literature lacks the exploration of how the reconstruction and redispersion of catalysts during HMFOR especially by varying HMF concentrations, which is necessary for practical applications [35,42,43]. Here, we designed carbon layer-wrapped Ni nanoparticles (Ni@C), investigated in detail the role of active Ni species formed by reconstruction and redispersion in HMFOR, and explored the effect of HMF concentration (10 mM, 20 mM, 35 mM, and 50 mM) on reconstruction and redispersion. A series of electrochemical characterizations demonstrated that high concentrations of HMF accelerated the reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C. The electrochemical impedance spectra indicated that the high concentration of HMF was more conducive to promote charge transfer, thus enhancing the HMFOR performance. Specifically, the Ni@C catalyst possessed a higher current density and lower onset potential at 50 mM HMF, as well as a productivity of FDCA of 250 mmol g-1 h-1 at 50 mM HMF as substrate, which was 2.5 times higher than that at 10 mM HMF. In addition, we further verified by in-situ Raman, HRTEM, and XPS that a high concentration of HMF is more favorable for the transformation of carbon-encapsulated Ni grains into smaller-sized NiOOH grains, which in turn improves their electrocatalytic performance. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalysts synthesis 2.1.1 Preparation of Ni@C Typically, 8.72 g nickel nitrate hexahydrate and 5.76 g citric acid were added in 5 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, the dispersion was then stirred at 90°C to evaporate the water, resulting in the formation of a green gel-like material. The gel was moved to an oven at 100°C for drying to produce a precursor resembling a green sponge of nickel citrate. The Ni@C sample was then acquired by heating the precursor to 700°C at a rate of 2°C/min, purging it with N2, and keeping it there for 3 h. To guarantee complete carbon coating on the Ni, the Ni@C was moved to 1 M H2SO4, agitated at 90°C for 12 h, extensively rinsed using purified water, and subsequently subjected to freeze-drying for 24 h. 2.1.2 Preparation of Ni With an airflow of 100 mL/min, the Ni@C sample was calcinated at 325°C with a heating rate of 5°C/min. In order to assist in eliminating the carbon layers and produce a NiO sample, the sample was subsequently kept at 325°C for 2 h. After that, metallic Ni was formed by reducing the NiO for 1 h at 325°C with a 100 mL/min 10 % H2/N2 gas flow. 2.1.3 Preparation of NiO In brief, a 0.6 M potassium hydroxide solution was gradually introduced to a 0.3 M nickel nitrate solution to obtain a green precipitate. Subsequently, the precipitate was cleaned with deionized water, centrifuged (10000 rpm), and dried at 80°C. The resulting sample was Ni(OH)2. To produce NiO nanoparticles, Ni(OH)2 samples were calcinated to 400°C at a rate of 5°C/min for 4 h in an air atmosphere. 2.1.4 Preparation of Ni-NiO@C-4 and Ni-NiO@C-8 Ni@C were calcinated at 180°C for 4 h or 8 h in 1 % O2/Ar gas with a heating rate of 2°C/min, respectively. They were named Ni-NiO@C-4 and Ni-NiO@C-8, respectively. 2.2 Electrochemical experiments Electrochemical measurements were performed using a CHI 760E workstation in an H-cell, employing a three-electrode system. The H-cell was partitioned into two distinct compartments (cathodic and anodic chambers) using a Nafion 117 membrane. A Hg/HgO and a Pt mesh were employed as the reference and counter electrode. All potentials measured relative to Hg/HgO were calculated to the RHE scale, and this conversion is made through the Nernst equation: E (vs. RHE) = 0.098 V + E (vs. Hg/HgO) + 0.0591*pH. To fabricate the working electrode, 750 μL isopropanol and 230 μL deionized water were combined with 5 mg of catalyst and 20 μL of 5 % Nafion solution. Following 2 h of sonication, the prepared ink (200 μL) was applied to a 1 cm² carbon paper to fabricate a working electrode. To ensure data accuracy, the working electrode was pre-activated by performing 30 cycles of linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in 1 M KOH (1.2-1.7 V vs. RHE, 5 mV s-1) before the electrochemical reaction (Fig. S1). The LSV test was conducted in 1.0 M KOH and varying HMF concentrations. The potentiostatic electrolysis (1.45 V vs. RHE) tests were used to analyze the yield of FDCA and conversion of HMF. All electrochemical measurements were performed with 85 % iR compensation for the solution resistance-induced ohmic potential drop. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was investigated with an AC signal amplitude of 10 mV, and the frequency range was 105 - 10-2 Hz. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were measured in the non-faradaic range (1.1-1.2 V vs. RHE) at various scan rates (10, 20, 40, 60, 80 and 100 mV s-1) to evaluate the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of the working electrode. In-situ Raman was performed using a LabRAM HR 800 Raman spectrometer, with the applied potential controlled by a Chenhua CHI760 electrochemical workstation. The experiment utilized a three-electrode system, consisting of an Ag/AgCl reference electrode, a catalyst-coated carbon paper as the working electrode (covered by a quartz glass plate), and a Pt sheet as the counter electrode. A 532 nm wavelength semiconductor laser was used as the excitation light source. The electrolyte (1M KOH and different concentrations of HMF) was electrolyzed at different potentials, and Raman spectral signals were collected and analyzed. 2.3 Product quantification The products were quantitatively analyzed using a UV-visible light detector (C18, 4.6 × 250 mm, λ = 265 nm) and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) on a Shimadzu LC-2050. Specifically, 20 μL of electrolyte is sampled, diluted with ultrapure water (980 μL), and then subjected to HPLC analysis. A mixture of eluting solvents (70 % ammonium formate and 30 % methanol) was utilized for isocratic elution (injection volume: 20 µL; flow rate: 0.4 mL·min-1; run time: 15 min). The conversion of HMF, the yield of the corresponding products and the Faraday efficiency (FE) of FDCA could be determined according to the following equations: Conversion ( % ) = n ( HMF consumed ) n ( HMF initial ) × 100 % Yield ( % ) = n ( product ) n ( HMF initial ) × 100 % FE ( % ) = n ( product ) charge / ( 6 × F ) × 100 % Where F is the Faraday constant (96485 C mol−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterizations of catalysts The preparation procedure of the Ni@C catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 1 a. Citric acid was used as the carbon source and nickel nitrate hexahydrate as the nickel source, forming a nickel citrate precursor, which was annealed at high temperature to produce the Ni@C catalyst with Ni completely encapsulated in carbon layers. As illustrated in Fig. 1b, the morphology of Ni@C was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Ni@C consists of spherical particles of uniform size, in which the average size of Ni nanoparticles is 5.9 nm. Fig. 1c displays the HRTEM image of the Ni@C sample, revealing that Ni nanoparticles are tightly encapsulated by carbon layers, with a lattice spacing of 3.34 Å observed within the carbon layers. The (111) crystalline plane of Ni nanoparticles corresponds to a lattice spacing of 2.03 Å, with no detectable oxide layers present on the surface. In addition, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis revealed a homogeneous distribution of Ni and C elements in the Ni@C catalyst (Fig. 1d), providing additional evidence for the encapsulation of Ni metal particles by the carbon layers. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyzed the crystal structure of Ni@C sample. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, the characteristic peaks at 44.6 °, 51.7 °, and 76.5 ° correspond to the cubic Ni metal phase of the Fm-3m (225) space group, which matched the standard card [JCPD 87-0712] [41]. The packet peak near 25.8 ° is attributed to the amorphous structure of the carbon layers [44]. Raman spectroscopy confirmed the existence of defects in the carbon layers of Ni@C. The D band (1341 cm-1), representing carbon defects, is higher than the graphitized G band (1590 cm-1) [45]. The formation of carbon defects is related to the oxygen-containing functional groups in the carbon layers (Fig. 2b) [46]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was applied to further analyze the pore structure and specific surface area of Ni@C. Fig. 2c shows that Ni@C has a typical Type IV isotherm, indicating the presence of mesopores in the catalyst, with a specific surface area of 144.8 m²/g and a pore volume mainly concentrated at 0.28 cm3/g (Fig. S2) [47]. To explore the surface composition and chemical environment of Ni@C, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied. The XPS total spectrum of Ni@C confirms the existence of Ni, C and O elements (Fig. S3). The XPS spectrum of Ni 2p proved that the Ni@C sample contained metallic Ni (Fig. 2d) [44]. The C 1s XPS spectrum indicated that the carbon layer contains C-C (284.8 eV), π-π* (291.4 eV) chemical bonds and C-O (286.0 eV), C=O (287.5 eV), COOH (289.2 eV) oxygen-containing functional groups (Fig. 2e) [41]. The O1s XPS spectrum shows that there are C-O (530.3 eV), COOH (531.8 eV) and C-O-C (543.5 eV) groups in the carbon layers (Fig. 2f) [44]. The existence of these oxygen groups is related to the Raman spectrum's D peak (1341 cm-1) [46,47]. 3.2 HMFOR performance in a three-electrode system To evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of the as-prepared Ni@C electrode for HMFOR, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted in 1 M KOH, including with and without HMF. As displayed in Fig. 3 a, in scenarios absent of HMF, the Ni@C electrode exhibits an obvious oxidation peak within 1.35-1.45 V vs. RHE, indicating the generation of high valence Ni species. As the voltage increases beyond 1.5 V vs. RHE, the current density increases markedly, indicating the onset of OER. Upon the addition of 10 mM HMF in 1 M KOH, the current density of the Ni@C electrode grew rapidly above 1.35 V vs. RHE. At 1.5 V vs. RHE, the current density of Ni@C was elevated from approximately 3 to 70 mA cm-2, confirming its excellent HMFOR activity. As seen in the inset of Fig. 3a, the Tafel slope was employed to assess the electrochemical reaction kinetics of the Ni@C electrode. After the HMF is added, the overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm-2 was reduced from 1.57 V vs. RHE for OER to 1.36 V vs. RHE for HMFOR, and the Tafel slope of the electrode was reduced from 103.9 mV dec-1 to 45.4 mV dec-1, and this result demonstrates that Ni@C has a lower overpotential and a faster electron transfer rate in HMFOR. Subsequently, we varied the concentration of HMF to analyze its effect on the electrocatalytic performance of Ni@C. As presented in Fig. 3b, the current density progressively increased as the HMF concentrations rose, indicating the promotion of electrochemical reaction by higher reaction concentration. However, adding a higher concentration of HMF (120 and 150 mM) resulted in a steady current density, as the reaction may approach the limit of diffusion control (Fig. S4). Fig. 3c shows the Tafel slopes of Ni@C electrode at different HMF concentrations. For 50 mM HMF, the Tafel slope of 43.1 mV dec-1 is a little bit lower than that of 10 mM HMF (45.4 mV dec-1), 20 mM HMF (44.7 mV dec-1) and 35 mM HMF (44.3 mV dec-1), which indicates that Ni@C possesses a fast reaction kinetic at high concentrations of HMF. An in-depth investigation of the electrode reaction process and kinetics is crucial for understanding the electrochemical reaction mechanism. Based on the above data, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis of Ni@C after oxidation with various concentrations of HMF were performed. The diameter of the primary semicircle in the Nyquist plot was employed to characterize the charge transfer resistance of the electrocatalyst [19]. The smaller diameter indicates the smaller charge transfer resistance of HMFOR [45,48]. As illustrated in Fig. 3d, the impedance arc diameters are in the order of Ni@C-10 mM HMF > Ni@C-20 mM HMF > Ni@C-35 mM HMF > Ni@C-50 mM HMF, which suggests that Ni@C-50 mM HMF possesses the smallest charge transfer resistance. This implied that the transport of electrons on the surface of the electrodes is favored at a high concentration of HMF, which facilitates charge transfer between the electrodes and the electrolyte during the reaction [49]. This finding is consistent with the excellent catalytic performance of the catalyst and confirms that the reaction concentration induces an increase in the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst. To gain further insight into the intrinsic activity of Ni@C catalysts, the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) of Ni@C in the non-Faraday region was determined by cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves after the reaction with different concentrations of HMF as a means of comparing its electrochemical surface area (ECSA) during the HMFOR. Figs. 3e and S5 show the CV curves at different scan rates of fresh Ni@C catalyst and Ni@C catalysts after cycling at different concentrations of HMF. The CV curves of current density and the corresponding voltage sweep rate fitted to the CV curve at 1.15 V vs. RHE are shown in Fig. 3f. It can be seen that the Cdl of fresh Ni@C electrode is 0.3 mF, and the Cdl of Ni@C electrode increases about 8 times after five cycle tests. Impressively, the ECSA of Ni@C sample after the 50 mM HMF cycling test was significantly higher than that of the lower concentration, this result suggests that the high concentration of HMF might played a role in exposing more active areas on the Ni@C surface [50]. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the aldehyde and hydroxyl functional groups in the HMF molecule enable its electrocatalytic oxidation to generate FDCA contains two pathways: one is from HMF to HMFCA to FFCA to ultimately generate FDCA (Path I), and the other one is from HMF to DFF to FFCA to ultimately generate FDCA (Path II). Real-time monitoring of these complex reaction pathways is crucial for elucidating the reaction mechanism of HMFOR and improving the catalytic efficiency. In this study, we performed qualitative and quantitative analyses of substrates, intermediates, and final products using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (see Fig. S6 and S7 in the Supporting Information for details). Fig. 4b was obtained by periodically sampling the electrolyte in a solution containing 1 M KOH and an initial concentration of 50 mM HMF. The Ni@C electrode was operated at a constant potential of 1.45 V vs. RHE for 5 h. Changes in substrate, intermediates, and products were quantified at different electrolysis times. The concentration of HMF in the electrolyte decreases with increasing electrolysis time, while the concentration of the final product FDCA correspondingly increases. The effect of substrate concentration on FDCA yield was analyzed by performing constant potential oxidation tests of the Ni@C electrode in 1 M KOH electrolyte containing different concentrations of HMF. As depicted in Fig. 4c, with 10 mM HMF as the substrate, the FDCA yield achieved on the Ni@C electrode was 100 mmol g-1 h-1 after 1 h electrolysis period. The FDCA production rate escalated progressively as the HMF concentration increased, culminating in a rate of 250 mmol g-1 h-1 at 50 mM HMF concentration. In addition, we also performed multiple cycles to evaluate the production rate changes and stability of FDCA over Ni@C catalysts at different HMF concentrations (as depicted in Figs. S8 and S9). The reaction was conducted for 5 h each cycle and the electrolytes were updated after each cycle. The findings revealed that the yield of FDCA initially increased and subsequently stabilized with the increase in the number of cycles, indicating an enhancement in the catalytic activity of the Ni@C electrode. Furthermore, the FDCA yield and Faradaic efficiency (FE) at 50 mM HMF demonstrated a marked improvement compared to cycles conducted at lower HMF concentrations, rising from 71.1 % to 99.4 % and 78.5 % to 99.2 %, respectively. This indicated that Ni@C catalysts exhibit higher activity at higher concentrations of HMF. At the end of the fifth cycle, the production rates of FDCA at 10 mM, 20 mM, 35 mM and 50 mM HMF as substrate were 48, 100, 170 and 250 mmol g-1 h-1, respectively (Fig. 4d). The result suggests that Ni@C can produce FDCA more efficiently and faster in 50 mM HMF, which demonstrates that a high concentration of HMF is more favorable for the production of FDCA. To further prove the stability of Ni@C catalyst in high concentrations of HMF, we carried out ten consecutive cycles of HMFOR experiments in 50 mM HMF. In the tenth cycle, the FDCA yield of the Ni@C electrode remained at 98.9 % and the FE remained at 99.1 %, showing a similar trend to the fifth cycle, indicating the outstanding stability of the Ni@C electrode in high concentration HMF electrolyte (Fig. S10). Furthermore, the stability of Ni@C materials can be well evidenced by the prolonged OER reactions occurring at higher voltages (Fig. S11). In addition, we utilized the constant potential oxidation test to compare the current densities of Ni@C electrodes in different HMF concentrations with those in 10 mM HMF electrolytes. As shown in Fig. S12, four Ni@C electrode sheets were initially immersed in 10 mM HMF electrolyte, yielding nearly identical current densities. Subsequently, the electrodes underwent constant potential oxidation in electrolytes with different HMF concentrations for 5 h (Fig. 4e). For comparison, the electrodes were then placed back into a 10 mM HMF electrolyte for constant potential oxidation (Fig. S13). Notably, the Ni@C electrode subjected to 50 mM HMF oxidation exhibited a significantly higher current density, indicating enhanced catalytic activity at higher HMF concentrations. Based on previous literature analyses, Ni@C catalysts form smaller-sized species during electrooxidation, which in turn exhibited higher activity [41]. Thus, the observed enhancement in electrochemical activity in high HMF concentrations is likely due to the generation of NiOOH species by reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalysts. To further study the mechanism of reconstruction and redispersion, we first performed TG tests on Ni@C and Ni nanoparticles. As presented in Fig. S14a, the initial oxidation temperature of the Ni nanoparticles (217°C) was higher than that of Ni@C (155°C), suggesting that carbon layers facilitate oxidation of the encapsulated Ni metal, which may be related to the fact that the carbon layers could promote the migration of reactive oxygen species [51,52]. To explore the effect of pre-oxidation on Ni@C reconstruction and re-dispersion, we performed characterization and HMFOR tests on NiO-AB (prepared by adding acetylene black), Ni-NiO@C-4 and Ni-NiO@C-8. In the XRD patterns of Ni-NiO@C-4 and Ni-NiO@C-8, the content of NiO species [JCPD 73-1523] increased with the increase of oxidation time (Fig. S14b). At the same time, the peak intensity of element O increases and that of element C decreases, a result related to the oxidation of Ni metal and the depletion of the surface carbon layer, respectively (Fig. S14c-S14f). The TEM image of Ni-NiO@C-4 shows that the carbon layer structure is not disrupted and that the reactive oxygen species pass through the carbon layers to oxidize the internal Ni metal to the NiO species. Both Ni metal and NiO are exposed to the (111) crystalline plane, with a crystal plane spacing of 2.03 and 2.41 Å, suggesting lattice expansion during oxidation (Fig. S16a and S16d). The carbon-layer structure of the Ni-NiO@C-8 samples ruptured, and the generated NiO species spilled out of the cracks of the carbon layer. During the oxidation process, the Ni metal not only undergoes a reconstructive phase transition but also further redisperses to form NiO species with finer sizes (Fig. S16b and S16e). The relevant characterization of NiO is shown in Fig. S15, S16c and S16f, where XPS spectra demonstrate the presence of Ni and O elements, and TEM images show lattice spacings of 2.41, 2.09 and 1.48 Å, which assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of NiO, respectively. After nine consecutive HMFOR reactions, the Ni-NiO@C-8 electrode showed that the NiO spilled from high-temperature oxidation was not further dispersed to form smaller particles during the recombination process (Fig. S17). In situ XPS tests at the NiO-AB electrode showed that the phase transition and recombination process of NiO was very slow (Fig. S18). The results of the HMFOR tests are depicted in Fig. S19. The initial current density and FDCA yield of the NiO -AB, Ni-NiO@C-4, and Ni-NiO@C-8 electrodes showed significantly lower initial current densities and FDCA yields than the Ni@C catalyst. The above results indicate that pre-oxidation is not useful for improving the electrocatalytic performance of Ni@C, and also demonstrate that the encapsulated carbon layers help to promote the redispersion of Ni nanoparticles. 3.3 Effect of HMF concentration on reconstruction and redispersion of catalyst The dynamics of the intermediate phase in HMFOR can be effectively monitored using in-situ electrochemical Raman spectroscopy. Since previous work has demonstrated that NiOOH serves as the intermediate phase at applied potentials, we analyzed the reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalysts in different HMF concentrations by the signals of the intermediate phase using in-situ Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 5 , in-situ Raman measurements were performed on Ni@C electrodes after cycling stability tests in electrolytes containing different HMF concentrations. In 10 mM and 20 mM HMF electrolytes, when the applied voltage was less than 1.43 V vs. RHE, only the D and G peaks of the carbon layer were observed. As the applied voltage increased, the carbon peaks at 1590 cm-¹ and 1341 cm-¹ gradually disappeared, while the characteristic NiOOH peaks at 475 cm-¹ and 555 cm-¹ became increasingly prominent (Fig. 5a and 5b) [53,54]. In contrast, in 35 mM and 50 mM HMF electrolytes, the formation of NiOOH was initiated at 1.42 V vs. RHE, with a more pronounced signal of the characteristic peaks in the 50 mM HMF electrolyte. These results suggest that higher HMF concentrations are more conducive to the generation of the NiOOH intermediate phase in this system (Fig. 5c and 5d). Furthermore, we carried out TEM characterization to explore the mechanism of Ni@C catalyst activity enhancement in high concentration HMF through microstructure. As depicted in Fig. 6a-6f , we compared the morphology changes of Ni@C after electrooxidation in 10 mM, 20 mM and 50 mM HMF for 5 h. It was found that the Ni@C electrode displayed superior Ni dispersion in the high concentration of HMF, and the carbon layer ruptured relatively larger, which provided evidence for the generation of more Ni(OH)₂ with smaller dimensions. Meanwhile, the TEM images of Ni@C electrode following 10 consecutive electrooxidation cycles in 50 mM HMF further proved that the Ni particles were dispersed into smaller-sized Ni(OH)2 particles (1.0 nm) (Fig. S20). The above results also confirmed the increase of ECSA at Ni@C electrode in high concentration of HMF. To further investigate the effect of HMF concentration on the structural evolution of the Ni@C electrode, XPS analysis was systematically performed to monitor the reconstruction and redispersion processes. The XPS full spectrum, as presented in Fig. S21, revealed compositional changes under varying HMF concentrations. Notably, the peak area corresponding to the Ni 2p3/2 peak with a binding energy of 855.7 eV increased gradually with the increase in HMF concentration (Fig. 6g), and the peak area of O 1s also increased (Fig. 6h), indicating that more Ni grains are transformed into Ni(OH)2. Concurrently, the peak area of C 1s gradually decreased (Fig. 6i), suggesting the gradual rupture of the carbon layer and the surface of the carbon layer was gradually covered by exposed Ni(OH)2. The XPS results showed that the high concentration of HMF was more favorable for the transformation of Ni grains to Ni(OH)2 grains, which further proved that high concentration of HMF induces faster reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C electrode. Based on comprehensive experimental evidence, we propose a mechanistic understanding of the reconstruction and redispersion processes of Ni@C during HMFOR, as illustrated in Fig. 7 . The process initiates with the applied oxidation potential driving the transformation of metallic Ni in Ni@C into the catalytically active NiOOH intermediate phase, accompanied by characteristic lattice expansion [55]. The spatial constraint imposed by the carbon layers facilitates the spillover of NiOOH from the edges of the carbon layer and its subsequent redispersion, leading to the formation of smaller-sized grains [41]. Throughout the HMFOR process, HMF is oxidized to FDCA on the surface of NiOOH and reduces NiOOH to Ni(OH)2 species, the continuously applied potential continues to oxidize Ni(OH)2 losing electrons and de-embedding protons to reform the NiOOH active phase, generating a cyclic phase transition between Ni(OH)2 and NiOOH [56–59]. In high concentration HMF electrolytes, the electrochemical reaction from HMF to the Ni@C electrode surface has a lower diffusion resistance, and more active phases can be generated, which is conducive to the production of FDCA from HMF. Therefore, the high concentration of HMF reaction induced the reconstruction and redispersion process of Ni@C catalysts. 4 Conclusions We have successfully constructed carbon layers encapsulating Ni grains as electrocatalysts for the selective oxidation of HMF to the high value-added chemical FDCA under mild conditions. Through systematic investigation, we elucidated the promoting effect of reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C on HMFOR, and explored the influence of HMF concentration on the reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C. A series of electrochemical analyses showed that elevated HMF concentrations facilitate the transformation of carbon-encapsulated Ni into smaller-sized NiOOH species, thereby enhancing active site exposure and increasing the electrochemically active surface area. Furthermore, the accelerated HMFOR kinetics under high HMF concentrations promotes interfacial charge transfer efficiency. In-situ Raman, HRTEM and XPS characterizations further verified that high HMF concentrations induced accelerated reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalysts, ultimately leading to significantly enhanced performance of the HMFOR process. Overall, this study establishes a novel strategy for enhancing electrocatalytic activity through HMFOR-induced reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalysts, providing new perspectives for biomass conversion technologies. coredata.dc:description: The electrocatalytic conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) into 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) offers a highly effective and eco-friendly pathway for the utilization of biomass resources. For the widely studied Ni-based electrodes, enhancing their catalytic activity remains challenging due to the sluggish phase transition of Ni(OH)₂ to the active NiOOH. Here, we present a model catalyst of Ni nanoparticles encapsulated by a carbon layer (Ni@C), systematically investigate the role of active sites formed by reconstruction and redispersion in enhancing the electrocatalytic activity, and further explore the effect of HMF concentration on Ni@C reconstruction and redispersion. The encapsulated carbon layer contributes to nickel grain reconstruction and redispersion to form Ni3+ sites, thereby increasing the electrochemically active surface area. A combination of in-situ Raman, HRTEM and XPS characterization analyses showed that high concentrations of HMF electrolytes promoted faster reconstruction and redispersion of Ni grains encapsulated within the carbon layers to generate smaller-sized NiOOH grains, thus significantly improving HMF oxidation. This study establishes a novel catalytic pathway for enhancing HMF electrooxidation performance by reaction-induced reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Reaction-induced reconstruction and redispersion of Ni@C catalyst for enhancing HMF electrooxidation
